Title.evidence: Effect of Preoperative Physical Activity on Recovery after Breast Cancer Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: This parallel, unblinded, multicentre trial randomised women scheduled for breast cancer surgery.

Participants.evidence: Participants were recruited from a university and a county hospital in western Sweden. Eligibility criteria included women aged 18 years or older, excluding those with stage IV breast cancer or who received neoadjuvant treatment.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received an individual recommendation for 30 minutes of daily aerobic physical activity before and 4 weeks after surgery. The control group received no physical activity advice.

Objective.evidence: This trial aimed to evaluate whether a recommendation for non-supervised physical activity improves recovery post-surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was patient-reported physical recovery at 4 weeks post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using an online system with 1:1 allocation in permutated blocks.

Blinding.evidence: Neither participants nor outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between November 2016 and December 2018, 400 patients were randomised (200 per group).

Number_Analysed.evidence: At 4 weeks, 370 participants (180 intervention, 190 control) were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant difference was observed in physical recovery (RR 1.03, 95% CI 0.95 to 1.13) or mental recovery (RR 1.05, 95% CI 0.93 to 1.17).

Harms.evidence: Complications occurred in 15.6% of the intervention group and 18.4% of the control group within 30 days post-surgery.
